pullRequest.body:
Once to create the import all files without failing, the second time actually checking.

[Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/PR.20fail.3A.20Error.3A.20Process.20completed.20with.20exit.20code.201.2E/near/446419185)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [0c8ea53b90](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14077/commits/0c8ea53b90b0e77cd4440c197d37abe62118e2be)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Otherwise looks good. 

bors d+

:v: adomani can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Are you sure this actually works? I would think `mk_all` updates the import-only files in-place, making the second run succeed. Indeed, in the test run, the build step *succeeded* (I am not sure why checking the cache failed; relying on this seems somewhat brittle).

Perhaps this is certain to work (e.g., if checking the cache fails, or the warning means the build is noisy and fails later). If so, can you please add a comment? I don't think this is as obvious as it looks!

That said: thanks for investigating a better solution here; if something like this can be made to work, that's even better than just checking!

Michael, you can take a look at #14779.  The failure of the cache step is not really an accident: there is a discrepancy between what GitHub knows and the local status of the branch.  Thus, the modified branch asks for the cache for all the files, but GitHub only returns the files that it knows.  The difference makes CI fail.

If this convinces you, let me know, and I will merge.  If you think that there is an error, also let me know and I will not merge!  :smile:
And can you also update the PR description, please - at least for me, the reality is more subtle than the description sounds.

Thank you all for the reviews!

Bryan, I'd be happy to see CI being restructured!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10865180212/job/30151348909)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10865180212/job/30151348981)

Thanks for pinging me again. (Sorry for letting this wait for a while.)

Re-re-reading your explanation, this all makes sense and seems to work. I have two minor comments, and a request for explaining this in the code - so somebody in the future can save some head-scratching.

Thanks for pinging me again. (Sorry for letting this wait for a while.)

Re-re-reading your explanation, this all makes sense and seems to work. I have two minor comments, and a request for explaining this in the code - so somebody in the future can save some head-scratching.
Why semicolon instead of just another command in the next line?

I think the quoting needs to be adjusted: in #14779, the logs only contained the work "there".
Can you use single quotes instead (or, shudder, escape the quotes)?
Can you please add a comment, explaining how this works: something like your explanation should do perfectly.

I do wonder, however, if this step will do any work.
If it operates on the local branch (modified compared to what github had), it will succeed. Can you either test and comment if it does work, or remove this step, please?

```suggestion
            bash -o pipefail -c "lake exe mk_all || echo "There are unaccounted for files, but I am not failing yet!"; env LEAN_ABORT_ON_PANIC=1 lake build --wfail -KCI"
```
Otherwise looks good to me!
I am still thinking about a more drastic refactor which moves the style linters (including `mk_all`) out of build.yml but that can be done on top of this.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CI): use `mk_all` twice

source.title: test: lake exe mk_all twice in CI

Michael, you can take a look at #14779.  The failure of the cache step is not really an accident: there is a discrepancy between what GitHub knows and the local status of the branch.  Thus, the modified branch asks for the cache for all the files, but GitHub only returns the files that it knows.  The difference makes CI fail.

If this convinces you, let me know, and I will merge.  If you think that there is an error, also let me know and I will not merge!  :smile:
